August would need to be close to double the July total. July had some strong returns in F9 and Black Widow, and while there are a couple releases remaining, the odds like very low (less than 1 in 100) that you could literally double that. On top of everything, increased acceleration of COVID means it's not a pure "return to normal" situation: https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-07-27/nyc-la-among-big-cities-joining-rural-states-in-cdc-mask-zone?srnd=premium&sref=i2Bc5OtW

Would need $883 in next 37 days, which is an average of roughly $23 per day. Weâ€™re barely hitting that this past weekend, so itâ€™s clear that youâ€™d need a massive new series of releases to get there and the pipeline doesnâ€™t look that strong.

If todayâ€™s numbers are to be believed, weâ€™re at 422 for July which brings the summer total to 821. That means we need 929 million to get to 1.75 billion, and there are 6 weekends to do that. Requires a weekend average of 154 million which will be hard to get given that the biggest hits of the summer (F9 and Black Widow) are probably behind us. But not impossible. Keeping a 10% probability.

Looking more into box office numbers convinced me to revise up substantially. [F9](https://www.boxofficemojo.com/release/rl192906753/) has grossed 137M just in the first 2 weeks it's been out [Black Widow](https://www.boxofficemojo.com/release/rl2122089985/) grossed 40M just in the first day, so will likely be at >150M just in the first 2 weeks it's been out July will likely be at least 500M, which means August only needs 100M for the question to resolve at >1B total.

August is generally ~2/3 of June/July. So assuming no change in underlying level, we'd get 400+400+400*(2/3) = 1.07B. Seems likely to either be at or above this number unless COVID gets really bad to a level that slows down re-opening / people's comfort levels. Seems fairly unlikely but not impossible.
Just a little adjustment, F9 and AQP2 are not the biggest titles released this season. After $400M takings in June, July is a good chance to break $600M.

I am not entirely sure why I have been so conservative about this but with June at 399m, and Black Widow and Space Jam to come in July, 1bn doesn't seem like such a high hurdle, assuming the delta variant does not cause major issues.

Not really sure if I think it will hit $1.75 or not, but can't pass up the opportunity to overweight crowd by ~30% in both of the only buckets where I think it'll end up.

My logic here is that there is already $388M in the bank. So, the question is now "will there be at least $612M box office gross in July and August?" With a baseline assumption that July will exceed June due to the release of Black Widow, the chances of some derailing event or policy seem slim to me. Therefore, I'm confident we will see more than $1B. The biggest question mark is whether we are seeing an upward trend in movie going generally or if we are seeing fanatics drawn to big releases. The answer to that question is going to be difficult to tease out over the next few weeks.

June 2021 closed with $388,790,878 gross from 78 releases (up to 4,179 theaters) and F9: The Fast Saga transpiring as the #1 release with a gross of $83,143,285 within just five days. In such circumstance, F9 could probably add some 125mn USD more over summer, resulting in a oversimplified box office gross total June through August 2021 of 1.1 to 1.2bn USD. The big questions are: /will the CDCs close indoor venues, enforce mask mandates even for the fully vaccinated, like important minds such as Dr. Fauci suggest, when the DELTA variant fully impacts? /will "Black Widow" (out: 09 July) and other "wide releases" repeat the success of F9, and how many other releases are there about to come which potentially break 100mn USD each? To date, I only see two: Space Jam: A New Legacy (16 July) Jungle Cruise (30 July)

"F9" banked $136M in opening weekend in China $200M to date (1).

The spread of the Delta variant in the US (10% of new cases under surveillance as of 05 June 2021) is likely to erase parts of the gross of the last week in July and impact most of the August releases and business in one way or another. Movie theaters are indoor "congregate spaces" and thus pose a risk in general, which will be exacerbated by the natural properties of Delta. Wearing a KN95 mask for two hours or more, on the other hand, isn't fun either, so my best guess is, those who are really into fresh hollywood releases are likely going to turn away from theaters and watch everything on their home screens via stream.
another decent weekend

Incomplete month-to-date gross is about 170mn USD for the first half of June 2021. The second weekend was far less active than the first one. I wonder if this is the result of the absense of an interesating release equivalent to "In a quiet place II" only, or if going to the movies at the moment has lost the appeal.

Probably the movie theaters have to compete for visitors at the moment with livecasts of important sports events (Stanley Cup, NBA Championship). Which brings me to my expectation for late summer: so far I have neglected any preference of US viewers for European football (soccer: UEFA EURO 2020) or the 2020 Tokyo Summer Olympics. If the past weekend is significant, then "In a Quiet Place II" will stay ranked #1 by box office at least until mid-August, since people will be busy doing or consuming other things. Successful movies really may score less box office gross on average than previously thought. Kids will be in summer camps again where applicable, that is probably why "In the Heights" and "Peter Rabbit 2: The Runaway" went off relatively poorly.

Maintaining my position this is going to come back high, it's 1 weekend in and almost $100M grossed.

In A Quiet Place II (#1: ~31mn USD between 01 and 06 June 2021) and Cruella (#2: ~16.5mn USD between 01 and 06 June 2021) grossed about 5% of the expected maximum outcome of this question in about 6% of the time line. If there aren't any bigger gaps between future popular releases, the result may come close to or even exceed 1bn USD. I will adjust accordingly.

The recent figures from May are quite informative:

*26-5 adjusmtent for lower than expected box office in May, and for this survey: https://observer.com/2021/05/marvel-black-widow-box-office-covid-19-film-recovery-disney-plus-hbo-max/* 1) establishing base rate: the 2015-2019 average box office gross was around 860 million USD. Variation is significant (2015 = 943 M USD, 2017 = 643 M USD) 2) For decenia now, there has been a slightly rising trend in gross box office. People are buying less but more expensive tickets (partly due to inflation). 3) the impact of competition from streaming thus far was not excessive. Income of streaming services rose over the Covid-19 pandemic, but not excessively. 4) There have been few bankruptcies among cinemas in the U.S. In the years leading up to the pandemic, the number of cinemas was on the rise. 5) Cinemas have been reopening in most states (with allowed capacity ranging from 20% to 100%). This has led to doubling of Gross Box Office in past months, with the income for April back to USD 189 million. 6) Looking at Covid-19 vaccination speed and trend in new infections, we can expect a reopening of most cinemas before or during the summer. 7) month-to-month variation in gross box office (very large) is largely determined by blockbuster releases. This summer looks like a strong summer for blockbusters, including a new Space Jam.

"Godzilla vs. Kong" is pushing $80M in April. Which will deliver around $200M for the month. (1)

We are starting to see enough data to make reasonable estimates. There are two factors to consider. First, the ability for releases to draw viewers (around 50% of normal). Second, the volume and quality of releases (around 50% of normal). For now, it seems that the release schedule isn't lining up with the summer time frame of this question. If we start seeing releases that were previously pushed into the fall move back toward the summer, I'd adjust upward. For now, it seems like we are on track for $400-$600M. Oh, and there is still an outside chance that theaters get shut down again.

"Godzilla vs. Kong" raked 80.5mn USD in NA box office gross in three weeks, despite simultaneous streaming start. Further tendency towards "normal" due to progress in vaccinations, a gross of less than 500mn USD can almost certainly be excluded at this point in time, if at least a few very popular movies head for debut in the three months of June through August 2021. It is still unclear how far a beginning fourth wave in the U.S. with involvement of variants of concern (VoC) can still halt reopenings at a large scale, but movie theaters will be eager to go back to business and thus fulfill all safety precaution requirements and stick to the official guidelines when their time has arrived (at least they've had plenty of time for preparations without spectators).

Based on my thinking, things would have to be 62% better than the past two months' pace to reach 500M in the given timeframe on average. However, there are at least 2 movies coming within the timeframe that may rack up a lot of money and by a lot I mean billion dollar movies; they may rack up less than 1B because of the restrictions but otherwise are potential 1B caliber movies. For now, I find it hard to believe that we forecast restaurants not to open fully this summer but the theaters may flourish. Then again, we expect the Carnival Cruise to set sail in July. I am torn.

Based on recent trends and the fact we are already at $116,984,649 as of April 18th, movie-going is undergoing a rapid increase (~doubling every month from February->April?). Not sure how many theatres are currently open, how many have closed permanently, etc. but as more of the US population gets vaccinated --> case counts drop, I see this trend continuing for some time. We are nowhere close to the ~$900,000,000 or so average monthly gross pre-pandemic (to be fair, we are unlikely to go back to that normal), so there's plenty of room to go up, if even for a short time as people are itching to go out and do stuff.
fine-tuning with vaccine roll-out

Historical data may not be a good source of data to use for this estimation because of covid. I looked at the domestic release schedule, subjectively identified 'blockbusters' that weren't getting simultaneous release on a streaming-service and then averaged the gross totals of previously released similar titles. I also considered the impact of covid on theatre attendance, and used Godzilla vs. King Kong (2021) as a bellwether for attendance under covid.
March 113m. april already at 87m. If we have 120m per month this will be 360m

"Top Gun: Maverick" is reported to have been pushed to November (from July 2021) by production company Paramount. Many other blockbuster movies in line for summer presentation could follow, since the success of a film is considered too dependent on initial box office returns, and production firms may not be willing to take a risk of spoiling the reputation of very expensive productions by showing under still limited capacity and disadvantageous consitions. This limits total box office gross to 1bn USD or less, with respect to an obvious surge of SARS-CoV-2 infections, stricter protocols under the CDC and the new WH administrations, and a possible fourth wave in the U.S. over summer aggravated by the spread of virus variants.

Cinemas are highly likely to re-open during a summer when a substantial proportion of the population will have been vaccinated and virus transmission is generally lower during the summer months. 2019 take was in excess of $3bn. Even if attendances are limited by capacity constraints, I expect demand to be robust, given a backlog of major releases and pent up demand from consumers. Even if capacity is constrained, price rises are likely to compensate for this volume reduction and allow for a total take well in excess of $1.75bn

Assuming these last three days of February 2021 will bring in $4-5 million dollars, that means on average February 2021 will end up being around 5% of the inflation adjusted average of 2017, 2018, and 2019 Februarys. I looked at all the forecasted movies predicted to be released June - August 2020. Based on the number of sequels related to previously popular box office releases, I took the predecessors of those movies and combined the gross box office income to reach an estimate to make my prediction. I also believe we will see a rise in people attending in person theaters due to vaccine rollout, which will increase the chances of a rise in box office income.
